## MATHEMATICS

9709/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 301, 308, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[770, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 384, 392, 399]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 880, 636]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 664, 212, 678]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 680, 728, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 75.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 71, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
1

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 92, 831, 501]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 518, 660, 537]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the graphs with equations \(y=\mathrm{f}(x)\) and \(y=\mathrm{g}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 549, 918, 584]]<|/det|>
Describe fully a sequence of two transformations which transforms the graph of \(y=\mathrm{f}(x)\) to the graph of \(y=\mathrm{g}(x)\). Make clear the order in which the transformations should be applied.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 808, 91]]<|/det|>
2 Find the coordinates of the points of intersection of the curve and the line with equations

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 101, 650, 123]]<|/det|>
\[
2 x y+5 y^{2}=24 \quad \text { and } \quad 2 x+y+4=0
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 88, 99, 104]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 606, 112]]<|/det|>
3 The coefficient of \(x^{7}\) in the expansion of \(\left(p x^{2}+\frac{4}{p} x\right)^{5}\) is 1280 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 127, 371, 144]]<|/det|>
Find the value of the constant \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 81, 99, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 920, 115]]<|/det|>
4 A point \(P\) is moving along the curve with equation \(y=a x^{\frac{3}{2}}-12 x\) in such a way that the \(x\)-coordinate of \(P\) is increasing at a constant rate of 5 units per second.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 129, 144, 145]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 127, 920, 160]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the rate at which the \(y\)-coordinate of \(P\) is changing when \(x=9\). Give your answer in terms of the constant \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 669, 144, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 666, 740, 687]]<|/det|>
(b) Given that the curve has a minimum point when \(x=\frac{1}{4}\), find the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 579, 91]]<|/det|>
5 The equation of a curve is \(y=4 \cos 2 x+3\) for \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant 2 \pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 106, 144, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 106, 529, 123]]<|/det|>
(a) State the greatest and least possible values of \(y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 322, 144, 339]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 322, 293, 339]]<|/det|>
(b) Sketch the curve.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 352, 892, 621]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 638, 144, 655]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 637, 918, 655]]<|/det|>
(c) Hence determine the number of solutions of the equation \(4 \cos 2 x+3=2 x-1\) for \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant 2 \pi\). [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 72, 109, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 91, 803, 303]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 333, 918, 384]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve with equation \(y=\frac{9}{\left(5 x+4\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}}\) and the line \(y=6-3 x\). The line and the curve intersect at the point \(P\) which has \(y\)-coordinate 3 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 400, 390, 416]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 85, 99, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 85, 144, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 556, 112]]<|/det|>
7 (a) Prove the identity \(\frac{\tan \theta+7}{\tan ^{2} \theta-3}=\frac{\sin \theta \cos \theta+7 \cos ^{2} \theta}{1-4 \cos ^{2} \theta}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 85, 144, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 730, 112]]<|/det|>
（b）Hence solve the equation \(\frac{\sin \theta \cos \theta+7 \cos ^{2} \theta}{1-4 \cos ^{2} \theta}=\frac{5}{\tan \theta}\) for \(0^{\circ} \leqslant \theta \leqslant 180^{\circ}\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 71, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
8

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[329, 91, 668, 300]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 314, 918, 348]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the circle with equation \(x^{2}+y^{2}-14 x+8 y+36=0\) and the line \(y=-2\). The line intersects the circle at the points \(A\) and \(B\). The centre of the circle is \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 363, 144, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 361, 433, 380]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the coordinates of \(A, B\) and \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 782, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the angle \(A C B\) in radians. Give your answer correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 351, 144, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 351, 555, 368]]<|/det|>
(c) The chord \(A B\) divides the circle into two segments.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 380, 435, 397]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the larger segment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 87, 99, 103]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 918, 128]]<|/det|>
9 The equation of a curve is such that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2} y}{\mathrm{~d} x^{2}}=-\frac{24}{x^{3}}\). It is given that the curve has a stationary point at \((-2,19)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 142, 144, 159]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 134, 369, 163]]<|/det|>
(a) Find an expression for \(\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{~d} x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 640, 144, 656]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 637, 918, 670]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the \(x\)-coordinate of the other stationary point of the curve, and determine the nature of this stationary point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 398, 91]]<|/det|>
(c) Find the equation of the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 400, 144, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 393, 918, 440]]<|/det|>
(d) Find the equation of the normal to the curve at the point where \(\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{~d} x}=-\frac{9}{4}\) and \(x\) is positive. Express your answer in the form \(p x+q y+r=0\), where \(p, q\) and \(r\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 77, 116, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 79, 151, 96]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 78, 918, 110]]<|/det|>
10 (a) The first, second and third terms of an arithmetic progression are \(4 k, k^{2}\) and \(8 k\) respectively, where \(k\) is a non-zero constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 127, 185, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 125, 349, 144]]<|/det|>
(i) Find the value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 495, 188, 512]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 495, 606, 512]]<|/det|>
(ii) Find the sum of the first 20 terms of the progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 918, 108]]<|/det|>
(b) The fourth and sixth terms of a geometric progression are 36 and 6 respectively. The common ratio of the progression is positive.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 116, 918, 160]]<|/det|>
Find the sum to infinity of the progression. Give your answer in the form \(\frac{a}{\sqrt{b}-c}\), where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 109, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 78, 144, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 715, 95]]<|/det|>
11 (a) Express \(x^{2}+4 x+2\) in the form \((x+a)^{2}+b\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 358, 468, 375]]<|/det|>
<pre>The functions \(f\) and \(g\) are defined as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[367, 384, 631, 405]]<|/det|>
<pre>\[
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{f}(x)=x^{2}+4 x+2 \quad \text { for } x \leqslant-2 \\
& \mathrm{g}(x)=-x-4 \quad \text { for } x \geqslant-2
\end{aligned}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 450, 144, 466]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 450, 185, 466]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 447, 435, 466]]<|/det|>
(b) (i) Find an expression for \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 78, 180, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 76, 460, 96]]<|/det|>
(ii) Find an expression for \(\left(\mathrm{gf}\right)^{-1}(x)\).

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 72, 567, 88]]<|/det|>
